field_reports.description:
• Summary of Tropical Weather Developments (15–24 July 2025):

    • 15 July: LPA 07f monitored inside PAR with medium chance of development.

    • 16 July: LPA 07f developed into Tropical Depression "CRISING"; TCWS No. 1 hoisted in parts of Luzon.

    • 17–18 July: "CRISING" maintained strength, moved northwest, and was located east of Aparri, Cagayan.

    • 19 July: "CRISING" intensified into a Severe Tropical Storm and exited PAR.

    • 21 July: New LPA 07h formed east of Calayan, Cagayan.

    • 22 July:

      • LPA 07g developed into Tropical Depression "DANTE".

      • LPA 07h had medium chance of development.

    • 23 July:

      • "DANTE" intensified into Tropical Storm "DANTE" (Francisco), moving toward the Ryukyu Islands.

      • LPA 07h developed into Tropical Depression "EMONG", then into a Tropical Storm over the West Philippine Sea.

    • 24 July:

      • Tropical Storm "DANTE" exited PAR in the afternoon.

      • Tropical Depression outside PAR (formerly LPA 07i) intensified into Tropical Storm "KROSA".

      • EMONG intensified into Typhoon "EMONG" (Co-May) by 8 AM and remained nearly stationary west of Pangasinan. It was expected to make landfall over La Union or Ilocos Sur early on 25 July, with potential weakening after landfall.

A total of 765,869 families or 2,733,646 individuals were affected in 3,712 barangays in Regional 1, 2, 3, 4A, 4B, 5, 6, 7, 9, 10, 11, 12, CARAGA, BARMM, CAR, NCR, and Negros Island Region (NIR). Of which, 40,487 families or 147,521 individuals were served inside 1,117 ECs and 23,830 families or 97,958 individuals were served outside ECs. 

A total of 2,431 damaged houses are reported in Region 1, Region 2, Region 3, CALABARZON, MIMAROPA, Region 5, Region 6, Region 9, Region 10, Region 11, Region
12, CARAGA, BARMM, CAR, NIR.

 

Source:

DOST PAGASA Tropical Cyclone Bulletin No. 8 for TS Dante as of 24 July 2025, 11 A

DOST PAGASA Tropical Cyclone Bulletin No. 8 for TY Emong as of 24 July 2025, 2 PM

NDRRMC SitRep No. 14 for the Combined Effects of Southwest Monsoon and TC Crising, Dante, and Emong as of 24 July 2025, 6 AM

results.name: PHL: Cyclone - 07-2025 - Tropical Cyclone Crising "Wipha"
results.summary:
On 15 July 2025 at 2:00 PM, a Low-Pressure Area (LPA 07F) was monitored inside the Philippine Area of Responsibility (PAR) with a "medium" potential to develop into a tropical depression within the next 24 hours.

 By 3:00 PM, LPA 07F was estimated to be located 1,040 km east of Southeastern Luzon. Meanwhile, the Southwest Monsoon was affecting the rest of the country.

 On 16 July 2025 at 8:00 AM, LPA 07F developed into Tropical Depression “CRISING”. By 11:00 PM, it had slightly intensified as it moved northwestward over the sea east of the Bicol Region.

A total of 7,501 families or 23,918 individuals were affected in 56 barangays in region 6, 7, and 12. Of which, 115 families or 117 individuals were served inside 6 ECs and 106 families or 526 individuals were served outside ECs.

field_reports.description:
On November 9 at 2 AM, a low-pressure area (LPA) entered the Philippine Area of Responsibility (PAR), and PAGASA named it "NIKA" with the international name "TORAJI." By 8 AM, the LPA, located east of Southern Luzon, had developed into a Tropical Depression. On the same day at 5 PM, "NIKA" intensified into a Tropical Storm.

 

At 5 AM on November 10, "NIKA" intensified into a Severe Tropical Storm as it underwent rapid intensification.

 

On November 11 at 5 AM, "NIKA" strengthened into a Typhoon as it neared the boundary between Isabela and Aurora. By 8:10 AM that same day, it made landfall in Dilasag, Aurora, and started moving across Northern Luzon. On the evening of Monday, “NIKA” had weakened from a Typhoon to a Severe Tropical Storm and exited Luzon's landmass through Ilocos Sur.

 

PAGASA reported that Severe Tropical Storm “NIKA” exited the Philippine Area of Responsibility (PAR) at 2 PM on November 12. However, another Tropical Storm, “OFEL,” which entered the PAR at 3 AM on the same day, slightly intensified as it moved northwestward over the Philippine Sea.

 

A total of 52,551 families or 195,532 persons were affected. Of which, 9,275 families or 28,104 persons were served inside 562 ECs and 4,658 families or 15,600 persons were served outside ECs.

A total of 325 damaged houses are reported in Region 1, Region 2, Region 3, CAR. Of which, 280 are partially damaged and 45 are totally damaged.

field_reports.description:
On November 3, at 5 PM, a low-pressure area located outside the Philippine Area of Responsibility (PAR) developed into a tropical depression. It maintained its strength while accelerating northwestward.

As it entered the Philippine Area of Responsibility (PAR) early in the morning of November 4, it intensified into a Tropical Storm and was given the local name "MARCE," with the international designation "YINXING." By 11 PM the same day, "MARCE" underwent further intensification, rapidly developing into a Severe Tropical Storm

By 11 AM on November 5, Tuesday, "MARCE" had strengthened into a Typhoon, marking a significant increase in intensity as it continued its northwestward movement.

Typhoon "MARCE" made landfall twice on Thursday, November 7, first in Santa Ana, Cagayan, at 3:40 PM, and later in Sanchez-Mira, Cagayan, at 9 PM

At 4 PM on November 8, Typhoon "MARCE" exited the Philippine Area of Responsibility (PAR), but its trough continued to bring scattered rains and thunderstorms to Ilocos Norte and Ilocos Sur over the next 24 hours.

A total of 76,622 families or 261,787 persons were affected. Of which, 4,559 families or 13,887 persons were served inside 230 ECs and 4,176 families or 12,916 persons were served outside ECs.

A total of 20,930 houses were damaged from Region 1, 2 and CAR, of which 20,038 are partially damaged and 892 are totally damaged. (NDRRMC Report #7)

field_reports.description:
On 21 October 2024, Tropical Depression "Kristine" (international name: "Trami") entered the Philippine Area of Responsibility. By 5:00 PM, it was moving westward over the Philippine Sea with maximum winds of 55 km/h and gusts of up to 70 km/h. By 2:00 AM on 22 October, it intensified into a Tropical Storm and further strengthened into a Severe Tropical Storm by 24 October.

At 12:30 AM on 24 October, "Kristine" made landfall over Divilacan, Isabela. As of 5:00 AM, it began gradually decelerating as it moved northwestward over Northern Luzon.

At 5:00 PM of 25 October, "Kristine" accelerated outside Philippine Area of Responsbility (PAR).[1]

A total of   1,789,276 families or 7,134,954 persons were affected. Of which, 121,814 families or 531,687 persons were served inside 5,872 ECs and 84,137 families or 403,727 persons were served outside ECs.[2]

At 10 PM of 26 October, Tropical Storm "Kong-rey" has entered PAR and was given the local name of "LEON".[3] As of reporting, TC Leon is now at Severe Tripocal Storm Category and is expected to reach Typhoon Category within the day.[4]

With this, the National Society has escalated the requeste from DREF to Emergency Appeal due to the following reasons: 

1. The affected population of TC Kristine continue to rise. Widespread flooding remains in some areas, with severe disruptions to basic services and shelter. 

2. Anticipated impact of TC Leon in Northern Luzon: Forecasts indicate Northern Luzon may soon be affected, compounding the challenges already facing communities impacted by TC Kristine.

[1] DOST PAGASA TCB #28 as of 25 October 2024, 10 PM
[2] NDRRMC SitRep No. 15 for TC KRISTINE as of 29 October 2024, 8 AM
[3] DOST PAGASA TCB #1 as of 26 October 2024, 11 PM
[4] DOST PAGASA TCB #10 as of 29 October 2024, 5 AM

results.name: Philippines: Typhoons and Floods - 2024
results.summary:
In less than a month, the Philippines experienced a series of six tropical cyclones that had devastating impacts on the country. Among these were Typhoons Kristine (international name Trami), Leon (Kong Rey), Marce (Yinxing), Nika (Toraji), Ofel (Usagi), and Pepito (Manyi), each contributing to the widespread destruction and challenges faced by the affected communities.

Severe Tropical Storm (STS) Kristine (Trami) entered the Philippine Area of Responsibility (PAR) as a tropical depression on 21 October 2024. It affected the entire Luzon and Visayas island regions extending to parts of Mindanao in the south. Even before making landfall, it caused severe flooding and landslides that impacted a significant number of people, especially in areas that were hit by the trough. The heavy rainfall led to lahar (destructive mudflows) flowing from Mount Mayon Volcano in the Bicol Region, which severely impacted both lives and livelihoods. 

On 24 October, STS Kristine made landfall in Isabela province in northeast Luzon, then crossed to Ifugao, Mountain Province, and Ilocos Sur province on the same day. Kristine exited Luzon through Ilocos Sur, however, the trough of the STS continued to unleash heavy rain and winds across vast areas, severely impacting Regions III, IV-A, and V. On 25 October, STS Kristine exited the PAR and made landfall in Vietnam on 27 October. In the Philippines, STS Kristine was the 11th tropical cyclone in 2024, out of an annual average of 20 tropical cyclones that typically affect the country. 

Following STS Kristine, Super Typhoon Leon (international name Kong-Rey) entered the PAR on 26 October. It passed over the far northern region of Luzon, affecting some of the remote islands in the area. Leon brought typhoon-strong winds, heavy rain, flooding, and landslides to the northern islands and the extreme northern mainland of the Philippines before exiting on 1 November.  

Tropical Storm (TS) Marce entered the PAR on 4 November and made landfall in Region II (Cagayan) on 7 November. The Cagayan Valley region experienced continuous heavy rains and widespread impacts due to Marce, which also affected parts of Region I, the CAR, and Region III. 

After the exit of TS Marce, Tropical Cyclone (TC) Nika (Toraji) entered the PAR as a Low-Pressure Area on 9 November 2024. Nika later intensified into a typhoon and made landfall in the vicinity of Dilasag, Aurora (Region II), causing significant effects in Region I, Region III, and Region IV-A while two other weather disturbances with significant TC potential were hovering outside the PAR. The onslaught continued with Super Typhoon Ofel (Usagi), which entered PAR on 12 November and struck Baggao, Cagayan on 14 November, and Super Typhoon Pepito (Man-Yi), which entered PAR on 14 November, making its first landfall in Panganiban, Catanduanes on 16 November, followed by a second landfall in Dipaculao, Aurora on 17 November.

In an unprecedented event, the Philippines experienced a succession of devastating tropical storms within a single month, a first in the nation's recorded history. As a result, the same areas have been impacted repeatedly, with multiple tropical cyclones and associated hazards significantly intensifying the disasters. This escalation is attributed to existing vulnerabilities and a limited capacity for recovery, compounded by the frequency and recurrence of these events. This rapid series of tropical cyclones has inflicted extensive damage across various regions, severely impacting communities that are already grappling with vulnerabilities and limited resources.

Summary of the disaster situation 

The sequence of 6 natural disasters has devastating staggering impact on 14.3 million people. A total of 174 deaths, 148 injuries and 25 cases of missing people have been reported to date. More than 1.4 million individuals have been displaced, and damage has been sustained to a total of 315,777 houses of which 36,000 houses are reported to be totally damaged. Affected communities are confronting critical shortages of water, sanitation, food, and healthcare.

As of 6 January 2025, two and a half months have passed since the first typhoon of the sequence struck the Philippines, according to the Report No 77 from the Department of Social Welfare and Development, a total of 11,520 families (47,275 individuals) remain displaced across Regions NCR, I, II, III, CALABARZON, MIMAROPA, V, VI, VII, VIII, IX, X, and XII. Of which, 3,091 families (12,436 individuals) are currently sheltered in 80 evacuation centers across Regions NCR, II, III, CALABARZON, MIMAROPA, V, VIII, IX, and XII; 8,429 families (34,839 individuals) are staying temporarily with relatives or friends.

In terms of shelter damage, Regions I, II, III, CALABARZON, MIMAROPA, V, VI, VII, VIII, IX, X, XI, XII, Caraga, and CAR are affected. To date, 205,319 houses have sustained damage of which 16,677 houses are totally damaged and 188,642 houses partially damaged. This data reflects the widespread and severe impact of the cyclones, highlighting the urgent need for continued support for displaced individuals and assistance in housing reconstruction.

In the past months, there has been an urgent need for immediate relief efforts, including the provision of clean water, food, shelter, and medical care to safeguard lives. The scale of the needs on the ground is immense, and the Philippine Red Cross, in partnership with public authorities and other organizations, is striving to assist as many individuals as possible with available resources. 

The cumulative impact of these typhoons has further weakened already vulnerable communities, indicating that recovery will be a prolonged process. The Philippines may expect additional cyclones and other weather disturbances in the coming months, which may affect the same regions, complicating recovery efforts and necessitating more resources.

Please see Appeal Documents tab for latest information about Philippine Red Cross' response and interventions.

field_reports.description:
Habagat enhanced by Tropical Depression Butchoy and Super Typhoon Carina brought heavy to intense rains across the Philippines that led to massive flooding in Metro Manila and nearby provinces. Below is the timeline of flooding events caused by the combined effects of Habagat, Tropical Depression Butchoy, and Super Typhoon Carina, including specific dates and geographic locations.
- On 11 July 2024, the Habagat has brought moderate to heavy rains to the provinces in western parts of Luzon, Visayas, and Mindanao causing widespread flooding in Mindanao.
- On 19 July 2024, two Low-Pressure areas were observed by the weather bureau. One LPA was located 225 km West of Calapan City, Oriental Mindoro, while the other one was located 840 km East of Eastern Visayas. During this period, the Habagat brought moderate to heavy rains over Northern Palawan, and Occidental Mindoro.
- At 8:00 PM on the same day, the Low-Pressure Area over the West Philippine Sea west of Batangas developed into a Tropical Depression with a local name Butchoy. Meanwhile, the other low-pressure area over the east of eastern Visayas also developed into a Tropical Depression with a local name Carina.
- On 20 July 2024, the Habagat enhanced by Tropical Depression Carina brought moderate to heavy rains over the western portion of Luzon causing flash floods in some areas in Oriental Mindoro. The same day at 11:00 AM, Tropical Depression Butchoy (with the international name Prapiroon) exited the Philippine Area of Responsibility (PAR), while Carina (with the international name Gaemi) intensified into a Tropical Storm.

- On 21 July 2024, Carina intensified into a Severe Tropical Storm and further strengthened into a Typhoon, meandering over the Philippine Sea on 22 July. This led to the issuance of Tropical Cyclone Wind Signal No. 1 in certain areas of Northern Luzon. Some areas in Southwest Luzon experienced flooding on 23 July as Typhoon Carina continued to intensify while moving northward, raising Tropical Wind Signal No. 2 in Batanes.
- Subsequently, on 24 July 2024 at 5:00 AM, Typhoon Carina further intensified as it headed towards Taiwan bringing heavy to intense rains in Metro Manila, the Ilocos Region, Abra, Benguet, Zambales, Bataan, Rizal, and Occidental Mindoro, while moderate to heavy rains affected the Cordillera Administrative Region (CAR), Tarlac, Nueva Ecija, Pampanga, Bulacan, and the rest of CALABARZON. This led to massive flooding in different areas and declarations of a state of calamity in the entire Metro Manila, provinces of Bataan, Bulacan, Pampanga, Rizal (Cainta, San Mateo, and Rodriguez), Cavite, Batangas, and Oriental Mindoro (Baco and Pinamalayan). On the same day at 5:00 PM, Carina intensified into a Super Typhoon and made landfall over Northern Taiwan.
- Habagat enhanced by Carina recorded 461.4 mm of rain in Science Garden station within 24 hours. This is almost a month's worth of rain in the area for July. This recorded rainfall was slightly higher than Tropical Cyclone Ketsana (Ondoy) with a 24-hour recorded rain of 455 mm in September 2009. However, Tropical Cyclone Ketsana, the second-most devastating tropical cyclone of the 2009 Pacific typhoon season recorded 341.3 mm of rainfall in just six hours. Both tropical cyclones caused devastating impacts such as massive flooding in Metro Manila and nearby provinces.
- Carina continued to weaken and exited the Philippine Area of Responsibility but continued to enhance the Habagat on 25 July. The Habagat enhanced by Tropical Cyclone Carina brought moderate to heavy rains over Zambales, Bataan, Pangasinan, and Benguet. At 11:00 PM, all Tropical Cyclone Wind Signal was lifted.
field_reports.summary: PHL: Cyclone - 07-2024 - Southwest Monsoon Enhanced by Typhoon Carina

results.name: PHL: Cyclone - 07-2024 - Southwest Monsoon Enhanced by Typhoon Carina
results.summary:
The Southwest Monsoon which has been causing widespread flooding in Mindanao since 11 July, continues to affect the western parts of Southern Luzon, Visayas, and Mindanao.

 

On Friday afternoon, July 19, PAGASA observe two low-pressure areas within the Philippine Area of Responsibility (PAR). At 3 PM, one LPA was 365 kilometers west of Tanauan City, Batangas, while the other was 865 kilometers east of the Eastern Visayas.

 

At 8 PM of 19 July 2024, PAGASA reported that the low-pressure areas to the west and east of the archipelago had developed into Tropical Depressions named "BUTCHOY" and "CARINA" by the weather bureau. “BUTCHOY” was located west of Batangas, while “CARINA” was situated east of Eastern Visayas.

 

On Saturday afternoon of July 20, 2024, the Tropical Storm “CARINA” with international name (GAEMI) intensified from a Tropical Depression into a Tropical Storm and further intensified into a Severe Tropical Storm on July 21. On July 22, Carina intensified into Typhoon category.

 

Tropical Depression “BUTCHOY” has exited the Philippine Area of Responsibility (PAR) on July 20, 8 PM.

 

Typhoon “CARINA” further intensifies as it heads towards Taiwan. The center of the eye of Typhoon was estimated based on all available data at 290 km Northeast of Itbayat, Batanes (22.9°N, 123.5°E) maximum sustained winds of 155 km/h near the center, gustiness of up to 190 km/h, and central pressure of 950 hPa.

 

Four cities/municipalities in MIMAROPA, region 11, and 12 have been declared under a State of Calamity.

field_reports.description:
Shearline

On January 16, 2024, the PRC started monitoring the flooding caused by the Shear Line. Shear Line affected the eastern section of Mindanao which brought scattered light to heavy rain showers and thunderstorms which resulted in flooding and landslide incidents in some areas in Region XI and CARAGA.

 

On January 17, 2024, the effect of Shearline has weakened. However, it continues to bring scattered rain showers and thunderstorms over Northern Mindanao, CARAGA, and Davao Region in the next 24 hours.

 

On 20 January 2024, the effect of Shear Line has weakened and was no longer directly affecting the country.

 

Trough of Low-Pressure Area

On 28 January 2024, the Northeast Monsoon and the Trough of the Low-Pressure Area affected Mindanao. The Trough of the Low-Pressure Area continued to bring light to heavy rains in Mindanao until 02 February 2024. This resulted in flooding, landslide, and other incidents in some areas in Mindanao.

 

Easterlies affecting the eastern section of the country.

 

As on January 31, 2024, Davao Oriental and Agusan del Sur are under a state of calamity. In addition, Davao del Norte on February 1, 2024.

 

In terms of essential lifelines, the communication signal is weak at Brgy. Cabawan, Agusan del Sur (as of January 30), while there is a power interruption in Mati City, Davao Oriental (as of January 31).

 

The local government announced suspensions of classes and work. All public and private schools in Sultan Kudarat, Davao del Norte, Davao City and Davao Oriental Agusan Del Norte. While Davao City the government employees ordered to work-from-home.

 

According to reports, the state of the dams and rivers in Davao de Oro, Lower Ulip, and Hijo River is critical level.

The local government announced suspensions of classes and work. All public and private schools in Sultan Kudarat, Davao del Norte, Davao City and Davao Oriental Agusan Del Norte. While Davao City the government employees ordered to work-from-home.

 

According to reports, the state of the dams and rivers in Davao de Oro, Lower Ulip, and Hijo River is critical level.

field_reports.description:
On the morning of December 3, 2023, at approximately 7:30 am, Catholic students from Mindanao State
University-Main Campus were engaged in their Sunday Worship inside the Dimaporo Gymnasium when a
sudden explosion occurred.

As of the latest update, the Philippine National Police (PNP) is actively investigating the incident to
determine whether a grenade or an Improvised Explosive Device (IED) was used in the explosion.
In response to the ongoing investigation and as a precautionary measure, MSU has temporarily suspended
all classes until further notice, and the entire campus has been placed on lockdown. Additionally, the
university has deployed extra security personnel to ensure the safety of the campus community.

 

No. of Areas Affected:

2 City  ( Marawi City and Iligan City)

No. of individuals Exposed/Affected

424  Individuals affected (Students, Teacher, Non teaching personnel)


  • 302 individuals already transported to respected LGU or already returned home (from Marawi to Iligan to other LGU’s)

  • 122 currently in MSU IIT awaiting for  LGU’s vehicle/support for transportation.

  • Currently assessing/counting the number of individuals in MSU Marawi Campus


Total enrolled : 6,000 individuals

Total students that are  out of MSU Marawi: 755 students 

Casualties

Deaths - 4 ( 1 from Tangub, 1 from Davao Del Sur  (teacher) and 1 from Lanao Del Sur and 1 TBI)


Injured -34; severely Injured 10  (currently in Amai Pakpak Medical Center)

field_reports.description:
A magnitude 6.8 earthquake hit the waters off Sarangani in Davao Occidental on Friday, 17 November 2023.

The tectonic quake occurred 30 kilometers southwest of the said area at 4:14 pm and had a shallow depth of 10 kilometers, according to the Philippine Institute of Volcanology and Seismology (Phivolcs).

The following areas recorded instrumental intensity:

Intensity V (strong): Matanao, Davao Del Sur; Jose Abad Santos, Davao Occidental; Maasim and Malapatan in Sarangani; Banga, Lake Sebu, Polomolok, and Tampakan in South Cotabato

  • Intensity IV (moderately strong): Magsaysay, Davao Del Sur; City of Davao; Don Marcelino, Davao Occidental; City of Kidapawan, Cotabato; Kiamba, Sarangani; Norala and Tantangan in South Cotabato; Bagumbayan, Columbio, Esperanza, Isulan, Kalamansig, Lebak, and President Quirino in Sultan Kudarat
  • Intensity III (weak): City of Zamboanga; Nabunturan, Davao De Oro; M’lang, Cotabato; Lambayong, Sultan Kudarat
  • Intensity II (slightly felt): Molave, Zamboanga Del Sur; City Of Malaybalay, Bukidnon; Kapatagan, Lanao Del Norte; Balingasag and Initao in Misamis Oriental; City Of Cagayan De Oro; Carmen and Pikit in Cotabato
  • Intensity I (scarcely perceptible): San Lorenzo, Guimaras; City of Talisay, Cebu; City of Dapitan, Liloy and Sindangan in Zamboanga Del Norte; Talakag, Bukidnon; Tubod, Lanao Del Norte; Alamada, Cotabato; City of Cabadbaran, Agusan Del Norte; City of Bislig, Surigao Del Sur

field_reports.description:
On 14 November 2023, the Shear Line brought significant amounts of rain over Oriental Mindoro, Quezon, Bicol Region, and Eastern Visayas. At 8:00 AM of 17 November 2023, the Low-Pressure Area (LPA) located at 935 km East of Northeastern Mindanao entered the Philippine Area of Responsibility. The combination of Shear Line and LPA
brought rains over Eastern Visayas and Caraga. On 19 Nov 2023, 2:00 PM, the LPA in the East of Surigao City, Surigao
del Norte dissipated. 

From 18 - 20 Nov 2023, the Shear Line brought rainfall over portions of Bicol Region and Western and Eastern Visayas. On 20 November 2023, 618 mm of rain was recorded in Catarman, Northern Samar. This amount of rainfall is above the 450 mm monthly climatological normal average.

Forecast Weather Conditions:

Area: Visayas, Bicol Region, MIMAROPA, Zamboanga Peninsula, Basilan, Sulu, and Tawi-Tawi

 

Weather Condition: Cloudy skies with scattered rain showers and thunderstorms

 

Caused By: Shear Line

 

Impacts: Possible flash floods or landslides due to moderate to at times heavy rains

Area: Cagayan Valley and Quezon

 

Weather Condition: Cloudy skies with light rains

 

Caused By: Northeast Monsoon

 

Impacts: No significant impact

 

Area: Metro Manila and the rest of Luzon

 

Weather Condition: Partly cloudy to cloudy skies with isolated light rains

 

Caused By: Northeast Monsoon

 

Impacts: No significant impact

 

Area: The rest of Mindanao

 

Weather Condition: Partly cloudy to cloudy skies with isolated rain showers or thunderstorms

 

Caused By: Localized Thunderstorms

 

Impacts: Possible flash floods or landslides during severe thunderstorms

 

 

A total of 81,050 families/307,087 persons are affected 503 barangays in region 5, 6, 8, CALABARZON, and CARAGA. 3,670 families/5,831 persons are taking temporary shelter in 104 Evacuation Center, while 9,080 families/37,834 persons are served outside the Evacuation Center.[1]


[1] NDRRMC SitRep No. 1 for the Combined Effects of Shear Line and Low-Pressure Area as of 22 November 2023, 8:00 AM

field_reports.description:
At 10 AM of 21 July 2023, the low pressure area of East of Southeastern Luzon developed into a Tropical Depression locally named “Egay” by the State Weather Bureau.

 

Egay intensified into a Tropical Storm on 22 July 2023 and further intensified into a Sever Tropical Storm on 23 July 2023. On same day, tropical cyclone wind signal was declared in effect. Egay intensifies into a Typhoon at 11 PM of 23 July 2023,  undergoes rapid intensification as it moves over the Philippine Sea, and reached the Super Typhoon Category at 7 AM today, 25 July 2023.

 

The center of the eye of Super Typhoon “Egay” as estimated based on all available data over the coastal waters of Aparri (Fuga Is.), Cagayan (18.7 °N, 121.4 °E ) with a maximum sustained winds of 175 km/h near the center, gustiness of up to 240 km/h, and central pressure of 9355 hPa. It is moving west southwestward at 15 km/h.

field_reports.description:
Mayon Volcano is placed under Alert Level III, indicating relatively high unrest, that Mayon is exhibiting magmatic eruption of a summit lava dome, with increased chances of lava flows and hazardous PDCs affecting the upper to middle slopes of the volcano and of potential explosive activity within weeks or even days.

 A total of 267 rockfall events and 2 volcanic earthquakes were recorded from 05 to 08 June, compared to 54 rockfall events from 01 to 04 June 2023. These events had durations of one (1) to three (3) minutes and transported lava debris within a kilometer range of the southern upper slopes. The volume of discrete rockfall events increased on 3 June based on the seismic record, signaling an increase in the rate of dome growth. Three (3) pyroclastic density current or PDC events on the Bonga (southeast) and Basud (east) Gullies were observed today at 6:18 AM, 9:53 AM and 11:00 AM. The PDCs lasted four to five minutes based on the seismic record and emplaced within a kilometer of the summit crater. In contrast, SO2 emission remains at baseline or background levels. The overall monitoring parameters indicate that very slow extrusion of shallow degassed magma is ongoing and is incrementally increasing in rate; i.e., effusive magmatic eruption is taking place.

field_reports.description:
In the past 24-hour period, the Mayon Volcano Network recorded six (6) dome-collapse Pyroclastic Density Currents (PDC) that lasted three (3) to six (6) minutes and one hundred ninety-nine (199) rockfall events based on seismic and visual observations.  The PDC and rockfall events emplaced lava debris on the southern gullies within two kilometers from the summit crater. Thin light brown ash from the rockfalls and continuous moderate degassing from the summit crater produced steam-laden plumes that were bent and drifted to the general south. 
The Albay Provincial Disaster Risk Reduction and Management Council (PDRRMC) on Thursday ordered the evacuation of residents in areas surrounding Mayon Volcano (6 km radius) in order to protect lives and properties due to its increased activity.

field_reports.description:
The Low pressure at Eastern Visayas area developed into a Tropical Depression, named as “Paeng” by the Weather Bureau last October 26 which then intensified into a Tropical Storm the following day. Tropical storm Paeng (international name: Nalgae) maintained its strength while traversing the Philippine Sea. Paeng is forecast to further intensify while moving over the warm waters of the Philippine Sea. It is forecast to reach severe tropical storm category within 24 hours and may intensify into a typhoon by Saturday, [Oct. 29]. The occurrence of rapid intensification in the next 72 hours is not ruled out.

The following areas were placed under Wind Signal No. 1 as of 5 p.m. on Thursday, Oct. 27: the eastern portion of Camarines Sur, Catanduanes, Albay, Sorsogon, and Masbate including Ticao Island and Burias Island, eastern Samar, Northern Samar, Samar, Biliran, and the northern portion of Leyte.

field_reports.description:
At 4 o'clock on September 25, the location of the storm's center was about 15.0 degrees North latitude; 124.1 degrees East longitude, about 300km east of Lu-Dong island (Philippines). The strongest wind in the area near the center of the storm is at level 14, and gust level 17.

From 01/10 to 02/10, in the midland, delta and coastal areas of the North and North Central region, there will be moderate rain, heavy to severe rain, and thunderstorms with a common total rainfall of 50-100mm. There are regions over 150mm, especially Quang Ninh and Thanh Hoa with 100-150mm, some places over 200mm. Day and night of October 1, there are areas in the North, South Central, Central Highlands and the South have showers and thunderstorms, with heavy rain locally.

 

 

There is a risk of flash floods and landslides in mountainous areas in the provinces from Thanh Hoa to Ha Tinh, especially in the districts of Quy Chau, Que Phong, Ky Son, Con Cuong, Tuong Duong, and Thanh Chuong (Nghe An province), Huong Son, Huong Khe, Vu Quang (Ha Tinh province). It is suggested important hydroelectric and small irrigation projects should be minded to prevent incident.

It is forecasted that in the next 24 hours, the storm will move mainly in the northwest direction, traveling 20-25km per hour, entering the East Sea of Vietnam. At 4 o'clock on September 26, the location of the storm's center was about 15.6 degrees North latitude; 119.3 degrees East longitude, about 850km east of Hoang Sa archipelago. The strongest wind in the area near the center of the storm is strong at level 11, gust level 14.

 

Dangerous areas in the East Sea in the next 24 hours ( with strong winds of level 6 or higher, gusts of level 8 or higher): from latitude 13.0 to 19.0 degrees North latitude; East longitude 116.0 degrees East longitude. All vessels operating in the danger zone are at high risk of being affected by strong winds, high waves and tornadoes.

 

On the afternoon of September 28, the tropical depression (weakened from storm NORU) weakened into a low pressure area over southern Laos, continuing to move mainly to the west and gradually dissipated. According to the latest update of the National Center for Hydro-meteorological Forecasting, from September 28 to September 30 in Thanh Hoa, Nghe An, Ha Tinh, Quang Binh, the delta and coastal areas of the North and Hoa Binh province have moderate and heavy rain. 

 

High risk of flash floods and landslides in Quang Tri, Thua Thien Hue, Quang Nam and Kon Tum provinces, especially in Huong Hoa, Dak Rong (Quang Tri), Phong Dien, A Luoi and Nam districts Dong, Phu Loc (Thua Thien Hue), Phuoc Son, Bac Tra My, Nam Tra My, Hiep Duc, Tien Phuoc (Quang Nam), Tu Mo Rong, Konplong, Dak Glei, Dak To (Kon Tum). From 28 to 30 September, a flood wave appeared on rivers in the North Central Coast, peaking in small rivers upstream of Ma River, both at warning level 1 and above WL 1. Risk of flash floods and landslides in districts of Ky Son, Tuong Duong, Que Phong, Quy Chau (Nghe An), Huong Khe and Huong Son (Ha Tinh).

At 8:00 AM of September 22, 2022, the low pressure area east of Central Luzon developed into a tropical depression locally named “Karding” by the State Weather Bureau which then intensified at 2:00 PM, same day, into a Tropical Storm.

 

11:00 AM, September 24, 2022, Karding intensified into a Severe Tropical Storm and into a Typhoon at 8:00 PM. At 25 September 2022, 5 AM, Typhoon Karding continued to undergo rapid intensification moving West Southwestward and reached Super Typhoon (STY) category at 8 AM. It continued it’s strength and made landfall on the following areas:

·        September 25, 2022, 5:30 PM in Burdeos, Quezon

·        September 25, 2022, 8:00 PM in vicinity of General Nakar, Dingalan

·        September 25, 2022, 8:200 PM in Dingalan, Auroa (typhoon-category cyclone)

field_reports.description:
Des fortes pluies continuent de s'abattre sur la ville de Kankan et villages envireonnants. Avec le débordement du fleuve Milö qui traverse la vile, tous les quartiers  et villages riverains sont sinistrés  et la plupart des populations affectées ont quasiment tout perdu.

L'une des causes principales est la construction anarchique dans des zones inapropriées (basfonds, abbords du fleuve) et le bouchage des caniveaux vient au second plan.

Le bilan initial est détaillé dans le tableau ci-dessous:

Personnes affectées 24 135. Hommes 10839 . Femmes 13 296 . Personnes blessées: 02. Personnes déplacées: 335. Maisons détruites: 93. Points d'eau affectés: 320. Latrines détruites: 375. Champs détruits 346 (environ 873 ha).

Si rien n'est fait en urgence, la tendance la plus probable  pour les victimes sera de retourner dans des quartiers sans eau potable, ni latrines, avec des maisons  lézardées qui resterons très humides pendant plusieurs semaines, avec tous les risques d'explosion des maladies/épidémies que cela implique.

field_reports.description:
As of  5pm,  04 August 2022, 2,529 aftershocks were recorded of which, 107 were recorded within the last 24 hours, 857 were plotted, and 59 were felt that ranges from 1.4- 5.1 magnitude, with the highest reported aftershocks in Tayum, Abra at Mag. 5.1.

Possible trenches on the affected areas are Abra River Fault, North Segment Philippine Fault, West Ilocos System and Libacan Fault. 

A total of 118,207 families/443,152 individuals were affected by the earthquake incident in 1,174 barangays in Region I, II and CAR, from which 884 families/2,968 individuals are taking temporary shelter in 28 Evacuation Centers, while 16,542 families/60,335 individuals are served outside evacuation centers in Region I and CAR.Ⴕ 

Out of the abovementioned affected regions. a total of 20 provinces from Region I, Region II, Region III, CAR and NCR are being monitored by the PRC, with a total of 23,943 families/ 98,691 individuals are reported affected from 164 municipalities/ cities.

And as of reporting time, the PRC is operating in two (2) Priority Provinces, which are the Province of Abra and Ilocos Sur, with a total of 21,606 families/ 88,504 individuals are reported affected from 58 municipalities/ cities, from which a total of 273 families/974 individuals are taking temporary shelter in 11 evacuation centers.

Province of Abra declared State of Calamity last July 28, 2022, through Resolution No. 180 Series of 2022, covering 27 LGU’s.

11 ACTIVE EVACUATION CENTERS (PREVIOUSLY: 8) * with 273 families/974 individuals affected (previously: 79 families/264 individuals)

**additional 3 evacuation centers in Ilocos Sur are a result of a preemptive evacuation done as a result of the heavy rainfall and possible flooding

Reported  Damages:
Worship and Tourist Places:
-	Cracks in St. Paul Cathedral, Vigan City
-	Cracks in Bantay Bell reported with partial damages
-	Calle Crisologo Heritage Houses
Abra
-	Aglipayan Church, La Paz reported cracks in walls and other parts of the church
-	Santa Catalina de Alejandria Parish Church Tayum reported with partial damages

Livelihood:
Damage related to agriculture amounts to Pph 3.8 million, covering affected infrastructures including farm to market roads, a diversion dam and communal irrigation systems. According to the DRRM team of DA-CAR, the road closures pose no significant effect to the delivery and transport of agriculture and fishery products to the trading areas in Metro Manila.

Abra
	Details for verification
Ilocos Sur:
	Earthquake has no major direct impact effects to the farmers 
	Farmland areas in the Magsingal were ruptured, while in Burgos, the possible occurrence of landslides was foreseen.
	Tourism sectors are affected particularly in Vigan - Bantay Bell Tower and Calle Crisologo and the SMEs are affected because they are not yet fully operated due to the damages and occurrence of earthquakes and aftershocks.

Local Situation Reports:
-	Liquefaction reported in coastal barangay of Pudoc, San Vicente Ilocos Sur .
-	Earthquake induced landslides in three areas 
i.	Brgy. Nagaparan, Danglas: Road cut landslide causing partial roadblock
ii.	 Brgy. Lipcan, Bangued: Massive landslide near residential houses and establishment 
iii.	Brgy. Suyo, Pidigan: Massive and extensive landslides with tension cracks
iv.	Brgy. Casocos, Nagbukel, ilocos Sur and Sabtan-Olo, San Isidro, Abra: extensive tension cracks observed
v.	Brgy. Tangadan, San Quintin, Abra: massive landslides close to a community
field_reports.summary: PHL: Earthquake - 2022-07 - 7.0 MAGNITUDE NORTHERN LUZON EARTHQUAKE (2022) #4 (2022-08-04)

field_reports.description:
At 8:43 AM of 27 July, 2022, a magnitude 7 earthquake occurred with epicenter located at 17.64°N, 120.63°E - 003 km N 45° W of Tayum (Abra) with depth of 17 km that is tectonic in nature. The earthquake was also felt in the neighboring municipalities.

As of 02 August 2022; 04:00 in the morning a 1, 956 aftershocks were recorded of which 53 were felt with ranges of 1.4- 5.1 magnitude. 

A total of 54, 502 families/215, 313 individuals were affected by the earthquake incident in 815 barangays in Region I, II and CAR. 1,581 families/5,226 individuals are taking temporary shelter in 43 Evacuation Centers, while 6, 490 families/27, 213 individuals are served outside Evacuation Centers in Region I and CAR. 

Region I, II and CAR declared suspension of work and classes. A total of 27 cities/municipalities were declared under the State of Calamity with Province Resolution No. 180 series of 2022 28 July 2022.

field_reports.description:
At 8:43 AM of 27 July, 2022, a magnitude 7 earthquake occurred with epicenter located at 17.64°N, 120.63°E - 003 km N 45° W of Tayum (Abra) with depth of 17 km that is tectonic in nature. As of 5:00 AM of 28 July 2022, there are 1,057 aftershocks recorded, 261 are plotted and 26 are felt. Magnitude ranges from 1.5-5.4.

II.  SITUATION 

A total of 19,486 families/79,260 individuals were affected by the earthquake incident in 246 barangays from Abra, Benguet, Ifugao, Ilocos Norte, Ilocos Sur, Kalina, Mountain Province, and Pangasinan. 1,622 families/5,819 individuals are taking temporary shelter in 26 Evacuation Centers, while 360 families/1,512 individuals are served outside Evacuation Centers. 

94 cities and municipalities from Region 1, Region 3 and CAR declared suspension of classes and 183 cities/municipalities from Region 1 and CAR declared suspension of work. 

2 landslides (earthquake induced) incident, 3 collapsed structure, and 3 falling incidents were reported. 11 road sections from Region 1, 2 and CAR are reportedly not passable. 38 cities/municipalities experienced power interruption/outage. 99 structures were reported with sustained damages amounting to 48,300,000.00 php. 5 infrastructures, machineries and equipment were partially damaged (Agriculture). 1 cities/municipalities experienced water supply interruption/outage.

5 June 2022 at 10:37 AM, a phreatic eruption is reported to occur at the Bulusan Volcano summit that lasted approximately 17 minutes and was recorded by seismic and infrasound monitoring by the Bulusan Volcano Network (BVN). DOST-PHIVOLCS is now raising the alert status of Bulusan from Alert Level 0 (Normal) to Alert Level 1 (Low-level Unrest).  The event was poorly visible through cloud cover over the edifice although a steam-rich grey plume at least 1 kilometer tall was observed from Juban, Sorsogon and was subsequently observed to drift west. Ashfall has been reported in Juban and Casiguran, Sorsogon.

field_reports.description:
At 2:00 AM of 04 April 2022, a Low-Pressure Area (LPA) entered Philippine Area of Responsibility (PAR) and is embedded inside another weather system, the Inter -Tropical Convergence Zone (ITCZ).  An  d on 5:00 AM of 09 April 2022 the Low-Pressure Area East of Mindanao has developed into a Tropical Depression and is named Tropical Depression "AGATON"  , making it the first tropical cyclone The tropical cyclone has been meandering in the Visayas’s eastern seaboards since Saturday, April 9 2022 as it intensifies into a tropical cyclone further intensifies into Tropical Cyclone and twice made landfall on Eastern Visayas prior weakening into a Low Pressure area on 12 April, 2022. 

The tropical cyclone have brought heavy rains over the over the regions of Visayas and Mindanao resulting to extreme flooding as rivers and water basins swell, and landlsides incidents in heavily rainsoaked mountanious areas, which in turn destroying homes, properties and infrastructures.

On March 26, 2022 at 7:22 AM, the Taal Volcano main crater was reported to have generated a short-lived phreatomagmatic burst which was followed by a nearly continuous phreatomagmatic activity that generated plumes 1500 m accompanied by volcanic earthquake and infrasound signals. DOST-PHIVOLCS is now raising the alert status of Taal from Alert Level 2 (increasing unrest) to Alert Level 3 (magmatic unrest).  

This means that There is magmatic intrusion at the Main Crater that may further drive succeeding eruptions. PHIVOLCS strongly recommends Taal Volcano Island and high-risk barangays of Bilibinwang and Banyaga, Agoncillo and Boso-boso, Gulod and eastern Bugaan East, Laurel, Batangas Province be evacuated due to the possible hazards of pyroclastic density currents and volcanic tsunami should stronger eruptions occur. The public is reminded that the entire Volcano Island is a Permanent Danger Zone (PDZ), and entry into the island as well as high-risk barangays of Agoncillo and Laurel is prohibited. In addition, communities around the Taal Lake shore are advised to take precautionary measures and be vigilant of possible lakewater disturbances related to the ongoing unrest. 

Five (5) municipalities with a total of eleven (11) barangays were within the 7 kilometer danger zone, five (5) barangays are in the Taal Volcano Island.

field_reports.description:
I. BACKGROUND:  At 11:00 AM of 12 December 2021, a Low-Pressure Area (LPA) outside the Philippine Area of Responsibility developed  into a tropical depression. It was later on categorized as a tropical storm with international name “Rai”, located East of  Mindanao with winds of 60km/h and gustiness of 80 kms, outside PAR. 
Upon entering PAR, TY Odette intensified and reached the super tropical storm category. And prior to its first landfall, it  intensified further into the typhoon category. TY Odette sustained this typhoon category before and throughout its 9  landfalls across the regions of Mindanao, Visayas, and MIMAROPA, up until its exit on 18 December 2021. 
II. SITUATION 
The first day of the new year, 01 January 2022, marks the second week  since TY Odette left PAR. Affected communities continue to struggle  
with the ruin TY Odette left behind. Looking from the immediate  aftermath of Odette to date, there have been changes in the  situation, especially since help and humanitarian efforts from various  groups and organizations, public and private alike, are being sent out to reach the affected communities. Still, with the extent of damage,  there are those that require a longer period of time to reach full restoration and functionality. Some provinces in the Visayas and  
Mindanao region still has completely no access to electricity, water  supply remains disrupted if not no access to both potable water and 
for domestic use, communication lines remain intermittent or none  at all, some roads and bridges are unpassable still obstructed by fallen  
debris, airports and seaports also sustained significant damage and  some remain closed and could not yet resume business as usual. Not  
to mention also the great deal of damage in the people’s livelihood – agriculture, livestock, and fisheries. Homes and properties broken  down. It is an understatement to say that these impede the daily lives  of our people. It is to this predicament that in the past two weeks, humanitarian  
efforts also persist non-stop. Activities such as distribution of hot 
meals, water distribution, clearing operations, restoring family links,  
psychosocial support, welfare services, setting-up VSATs, relief  distribution, multipurpose cash grants, among others, continue. 

STATUS OF AFFECTED AREAS
A total of 1,808,365 families or 6,695,591 persons were affected by TY Odette in 7,687 Barangays in Regions V, VI, VII, VIII, IX, X, XI,  XII, MIMAROPA, and CARAGA. Relative to this affected population, there are 89,257 families or 357,458 persons taking temporary  shelter in 1,489 evacuation centers in Regions VI, VII, VIII, X, MIMAROPA, and CARAGA, as monitored by DSWD.

I. BACKGROUND: At 11:00 AM of 12 December 2021, a Low-Pressure Area (LPA) outside the Philippine Area of Responsibility developed  into a tropical depression. It was later on categorized as tropical storm with international name “Rai”, located East of  Mindanao with winds of 60km/h and gustiness of 80 kms, outside PAR. 
Upon entering PAR, TY Odette intensified and reached super tropical storm category. And prior its first landfall, it  intensified further into typhoon category. TY Odette sustained this typhoon category before and throughout its 9  landfalls across the regions of Mindanao, Visayas, and MIMAROPA, up until its exit on 18 December 2021.
II. SITUATION 
TY Odette now well outside PAR, left a devastating aftermath in the  Visayas, Mindanao, and Southern Luzon Regions. Throughout its  course traversing the Philippine landmass, TY Odette brought about  heavy rainfall, severe flooding, threat of storm surges, and landslides.  In effect, it brought down power and communication lines, caused  water disruptions, made quite a number of roads and bridges not  passable, and dealt substantial damage to properties and several essential infrastructures. Ultimately, a significant percentage of the  population from the affected areas were displaced and sought  temporary shelter in evacuation centers. 
Six regions were greatly affected: CARAGA (Agusan del Norte, Agusan  del Sur, Surigao del Norte, Surigao del Sur, Dinagat Islands), Region VI (Aklan, Antique, Capiz, Guimaras, Iloilo, and Negros Occidental),  Region VII (Cebu, Bohol, Negros Oriental, Lapu-Lapu), Region VIII 
(Biliran, Hilongos, Northern Samar, Samar, Eastern Samar, Southern  Leyte, Ormoc and Tacloban), Region X (Misamis Occidental, Misamis  Oriental, Gingoog, Bukidnon, Iligan), and MIMAROPA (Palawan). 
This dire situation prompted the immediate rollout of hotmeals operations, clearing operations, setting up of welfare desks and first  aid stations, provision of relief, volunteers and staff mobilization,  damage assessments, coordination with key partners and  stakeholders, and the deployment of the humanitarian caravan.

Throughout its course traversing the Philippine landmass, TC Odette brought about heavy rainfall, severe flooding, threat of storm surges, and landslides. A province-wide state of calamity was declared in Agusan del Norte, including Butuan City.

I.	BACKGROUND  
At 11:00 AM of 12 December 2021, a Low-Pressure Area (LPA) outside the Philippine Area of Responsibility developed into a tropical depression. It was later on categorized as tropical storm with international name “Rai”, located East of Mindanao with winds of 60km/h and gustiness of 80 kms, outside PAR.  
 
Upon entering PAR, TC Odette intensified and reached super tropical storm category. And prior its first landfall, it intensified further into typhoon category. TC Odette sustained this typhoon category before and throughout its 9 landfalls across the regions of Mindanao, Visayas, and MIMAROPA, up until its exit on 18 December 2021. 

II. SITUATION
TC Odette now well outside PAR, left a devastating aftermath in the Visayas, Mindanao, and Southern Luzon Regions. Throughout its course traversing the Philippine landmass, TC Odette brought about heavy rainfall, severe flooding, threat of storm surges, and landslides. In effect, it brought down power and communication lines, caused water disruptions, made quite a number of roads and bridges not passable, and dealt substantial damage to properties and several essential infrastructures. Ultimately, a significant percentage of the population from the affected areas were displaced and sought temporary shelter in evacuation centers.

Six regions were greatly affected: CARAGA (Agusan del Norte, Agusan del Sur, Surigao del Norte, Surigao del Sur, Dinagat Islands), Region VI (Aklan, Antique, Capiz, Guimaras, Iloilo, and Negros Occidental), Region VII (Cebu, Bohol, Negros Oriental, Lapu-Lapu), Region VIII (Biliran, Hilongos, Northern Samar, Samar, Eastern Samar, Southern Leyte, Ormoc and Tacloban), Region X (Misamis Occidental, Misamis Oriental, Gingoog, Bukidnon, Iligan), and MIMAROPA (Palawan).

This dire situation prompted the immediate rollout of hotmeals operations, clearing operations, setting up of welfare desks and first aid stations, provision of relief, volunteers and staff mobilization, damage assessments, coordination with key partners and stakeholders, and the deployment of the humanitarian caravan. 

STATUS OF AFFECTED AREAS  

A total of 588,778 families or 2,348,754 persons were affected by TC Odette in 4,293 Barangays in Regions V, VI, VII, VIII, IX, X, XI, MIMAROPA, and Caraga, as monitored by DSWD. 

There are 112,966 families or 459,673 persons taking temporary shelter in 2,261 evacuation centers in Regions VI, VII, VIII, X, MIMAROPA, and Caraga, as monitored by DSWD.

A province-wide state of calamity was declared in Agusan del Norte. Butuan City has also declared state of calamity.

I.	BACKGROUND 
At 11:00 AM of 12 December 2021, a Low-Pressure Area (LPA) outside the Philippine Area of Responsibility developed into a tropical depression. 

It was later on categorized as tropical storm with international name “Rai”, located East of Mindanao with winds of 60km/h and gustiness of 80 kms, outside PAR.   
 
Severe Tropical Storm Rai entered PAR on 14 December 2021 7:00PM, and has been assigned the domestic name  “ODETTE”.

TC Odette made a total of 9 landfalls across the Mindanao, Visayas, and MIMAROPA regions before eventually exiting PAR 18 December 2021 12:40 PM. 

II. SITUATION
The exposure of TC Odette to the increasing vertical wind shear and the surge of the Northeast Monsoon led to the weakening of its trends. All flood watch alerts then has been lifted, as well as all previously raised TCWS; but TCWS # 1 remain hoisted over the Kalayaan group of islands.

TC Odette being well outside PAR, left a devastating aftermath in the Visayas, Mindanao, and Southern Luzon Regions.  

Its center is now located 320 km Northwest of Pag-asa Island, Kalayaan, Palawan outside PAR. It has a maximum sustained winds of 195 km/h near the center, gustiness of up to 240 km/h, and central pressure of 915 hPa; and strong winds or higher extend outwards up to 400 km from the center. We can still expect light to moderate with at times heavy rains over Kalayaan Islands

Considering the forecast scenario for TC Odette, there is a high likelihood that wind signal for Kalayaan Islands will be lifted before noon today.

STATUS OF AFFECTED AREAS  
A total of 202,650 families or 780,800 persons persons were affected by TC Odette in 2,322 Barangays in Regions Regions V, VI, VII, VIII, X, XI, MIMAROPA, and Caraga. There are 74,680 families or 279,623 persons sought temporary shelter in 2,060 evacuation centers in Regions V, VI, VII, VIII, X, Caraga, and MIMAROPA.

STATUS OF LIFELINES 
POWER/ELECTRICITY- •	Precautionary Power Outage (affected 7 provinces, 25 cities/municipalities)
-	Agusan del Norte: Butuan City
-	Surigao del Norte: Surigao City, Ozamiz, Tangub
-	Surigao del Sur: San Miguel, Bayabas, portion of Tago and Cagwait, Cortes, Tandag City
-	Cebu Province: Bogo City, Anapog, San Remegio
-	Cebu City: Naga City, San Fernando City, Banilad Cebu City, Portion of Mandaue City
-	Lapu-Lapu/Cordova: Panaon, Pacific, Kikilo, Abuyog, portion of Benit, Caaga, Malitbog to entire Sogod Bay Area
-	Bohol

WATER SUPPLY- •	Water Interruption (affected 2 provinces, 13 cities/municipalities)
-	Cebu: Pit-os, Bacayan, Tigbao, Talamban, San Jose, Klaubihan, Nasipit and some parts of Cabancalan, Liloan, Consolacion, Mandaue City, Mactan and some parts of Cebu
-	Surigao del Sur:  Tandag City

ROADS/BRIDGES
•	Impassable (affected 1 province, 1 city/municipality
-	Bohol: Loboc

TRANSPORTATION
•	STRANDED INDIVIDUALS

I.	BACKGROUND 
At 11:00 AM of 12 December 2021, a Low-Pressure Area (LPA) outside the Philippine Area of Responsibility developed into a tropical depression. 

It was later on categorized as tropical storm with international name “Rai”, located East of Mindanao with winds of 60km/h and gustiness of 80 kms, outside PAR. 

Severe Tropical Storm Rai entered PAR on 14 December 2021 7:00PM, and has been assigned the domestic name  “ODETTE”.

At 4:00AM of 18 December 2021 the center of TC Odette was located 240 km West Northwest of Puerto Princesa City, Palawan.

It has a maximum sustained winds of 150 km/h near the center, gustiness of up to 185 km/h, and central pressure of 960 hPa. Strong winds or higher extend outwards up to 400 km from the center. 

II. SITUATION 
Leaving behind a devastating aftermath in the Visayas and Mindanao regions, TC Odette steadily traverses its path as it prepares to exit PAR, approximately within the day. TC Odette made its 9th landfall yesterday in Roxas, Palawan as it moves west northwestward.  
It maintains its strength and is now threatening the Kalayaan Islands. 

Heavy to torrential rains over Kalayaan Islands can be expected. Moderate to heavy rains over mainland Palawan, Aurora, and the northern portion of Quezon including Polillo Islands. Light to moderate with at times heavy rains over Bicol Region, Northern Samar, Nueva Vizcaya, Quirino, Nueva Ecija, and the rest of Quezon. Under these conditions, scattered to widespread flooding (including flash floods) and rain-induced landslides are expected especially in areas that are highly or very highly susceptible to these hazard as identified in hazard maps, and in localities with significant antecedent rainfall.

•	FLOOD ADVISORY 
Flood watch remains in Davao, while areas previously placed under flood watch have receded. Other river basins and dams/reservoir (sub basin) are in normal level.  

•	OTHER WEATHER SYSTEMS
The eventual exposure of the TC Odette to the increasing vertical wind shear and the surge of the Northeast Monsoon will result to a weakening trend beginning tomorrow.

o	[24-Hour Forecast] 2:00 AM, 19 October 2021

results.name: Philippines - Typhoon Rai (Odette)
results.summary:
Summary

The Philippines was hit by Typhoon Rai, locally named Odette, on 16 December 2021 with gusts up to 270 km/h and with maximum sustained winds of 195 km/h near the centre making it the strongest storm to make landfall in the Philippines in 2021.

  • The latest government figures indicate more than 10.6 million people are affected in more than eight thousand barangays in Regions V, VI, VII, VIII, X, XI, Caraga and MIMAROPA (DSWD, NDRRMC).
  • Since the beginning of the disaster staff and volunteers from the Philippine Red Cross (PRC) have been helping affected persons with evacuations, search and rescue, assessment, relief, welfare, health, and water sanitation and hygiene (WASH) activities.
  • Through the emergency appeal,that was launched on 18 December 2022, the operation aims to meet the immediate and early recovery needs of approximately 80,000 of the most vulnerable affected households (400,000 people) in 15 chapters in Regions V, VI, VII, VIII, X, XI, Caraga, and MIMAROPA within 24 months.


Background

Typhoon Rai made initial landfall in Siargao Island, province of Surigao del Norte in Caraga region, northern Mindanao. The trail of Typhoon Rai crossed the Philippine archipelago from Caraga to Eastern and Central Visayas and Palawan. It made nine landfalls in Surigao del Norte, Dinagat Islands, Southern Leyte, Bohol, Cebu, Negros Oriental and Palawan. Tropical Cyclone Wind Signals (TCWS) up to level 42 were hoisted in many provinces across northern Mindanao and Visayas Island group, indicating destructive typhoon-force winds.

Typhoon Rai brought severe flooding and rain-induced landslides and caused widespread damage to high-risk structures made of light materials, damaging shelter, livelihoods, agriculture and infrastructure. The typhoon struck sections of northern Mindanao, an island that has experienced decades of unrest.

Initially, access to many of the affected areas was very difficult due to the devastation caused by the typhoon, making it difficult to precisely assess the extent of the damage, but early assessment by PRC showed that the extent of devastattion was enormous. Pre-emptively 332,855 people were evacuated, and approximately 300,000 people had to seek shelter in over 1,600 evacuation centers in the first weeks after the disaster.

 

Coordination

IFRC membership

PRC is working closely with the IFRC, and early financial resources were made available through the DREF for this operation. IFRC Philippine Delegation is supporting the PRC in disseminating updates to the IFRC network in-country. Seven National Societies are present in the Philippines: American Red Cross, Canadian Red Cross, Finnish Red Cross, German Red Cross, Netherlands Red Cross, Spanish Red Cross and Qatar Red Crescent Society. Partners briefing is organised daily since the onset of the situation to share updates and discuss the possibilities for supporting the operation. Several Partners have indicated their willingness to contribute and support the operation, while the funding confirmation is in process. The Operational Strategy will also provide further details on the Federation Wide approach which includes response activities of all contributing Red Cross and Red Crescent National Societies, and the Federation-wide funding requirement.


Movement

The International Committee of the Red Cross (ICRC) is also present in the Philippines, with an operational base and a warehouse on Mindanao Island. There is an initial indication of ICRC supporting the operation with prepositioned relief items in northern Mindanao. The PRC hosts Movement coordination meetings involving the ICRC and operational meetings to share information with partners. The IFRC and PRC are also coordinating with the ICRC on security-related considerations as well as on potential complementarity of action where this may be required.


External engagement

IFRC leads the Inter-Agency Standing Committee (IASC) Shelter Cluster in support of the Department of Social Welfare and Development, the lead agency in the Government of the Philippines cluster structure.

IFRC is continuously coordinating with various government and non-government agencies, including members of the Humanitarian Country Team (HCT). During the first weeks, HCT meetings were organized for situation update prior to and after the landfall of Typhoon Rai. Participating actors shared situational information and updates on their preparedness and response activities. The Inter-Cluster Coordination Group (ICCG) and Mindanao Humanitarian Team (MHT) members together with their partners are on the ground in many of the most affected areas. They are conducting harmonized needs assessments, which will be consolidated to an initial assessment report by OCHA.

field_reports.description:
The country is now experiencing the transition of the seasons albeit gradually. The weakening of the SWM, the strengthening of the high-pressure area over mainland Asia, and the expected northeasterly surge over Northern Luzon within the next five days, is indicative of the  transition and that the SWM season or “Habagat” is over. As per PAGASA, the SWM is officially over as of 15 October 2021, and the transition will lead to the gradual onset and progression of the Northeast Monsoon.

Onset of La Niña5
In another press statement released by DOST-PAGASA, recent oceanic and atmospheric conditions indicate the onset of La Niña, that is likely to persist until the first quarter of 2022. The phenomenon is usually associated with above normal rainfall conditions across most areas of the country. Forecasts suggests that four to six tropical cyclones are expected to enter/develop in the Philippine Area of Responsibility, most of which are anticipated to make landfall. There is a possibility that these TCs will enhance the Northeast Monsoon. 

Areas and population affected
The impact of TC Maring was felt across 1,797 barangays in Regions I, II, III, Caraga, NCR, and CAR, affecting a total of 257,595 families or 975,095 persons.

State of Calamity
The government of La Union declared a state of calamity in the entire province due to massive agriculture and infrastructure losses on October 15, 2021. Likewise, Ilocos Sur declared state of calamity on Monday, October 18, 2021. Palawan also declared state of calamity on Wednesday, October 13, 2021.

•	Pangasinan:  Flooded areas in Sta. Barbara already subsided, except Dagupan City (gutter to knee deep), Calasiao(3-4 ft)
•	Baguio City

•	Catanduanes

	Sagrada National road, Viga (minor landslide, no reported casualties/all passable)

	Livestock’s: 1,803,800.00
	Corn: 18,201,500.00
	Fisheries: 6,827,000.00

Shortly after TC Lannie exited the Philippine Area of Responsibility last 06 October 2021, another weather disturbance entered PAR. 

At 2:00PM of 07 October 2021, the Low Pressure Area East of Daet, Camarines Norte developed into a Tropical Depression and earned the local name TC “Maring”. TC Maring was felt across regions: Region 1, Region 2, Region 3, CALABARZON, MIMAROPA, Region 5, Region 6, Region 7, Region 8, Region 9, Region 10, Region 11, Region 12, CARAGA, BARMM, CAR, and NCR as it crosses the northeastern portion of the Philippine Area of Responsibility.

And, at 11:00AM of 08 October 2021 another LPA developed into a Tropical Depression, before entering PAR later on the same day at 11:00PM, earning the local name TC “Nando”.

TC Maring and TC Nando were observed to be embedded within the larger circulation of a monsoon depression, with the proximity of TC Nando, it assimilated within the circulation of TC Maring and later merged, which therefore formed a rather board and large circulation.

TC Maring only made one landfall at 8:10PM of 11 October 2021 in Fuga Island Aparri, Cagayan, before exiting PAR on Ocotber 13, 2021.  Meanwhile, the Southwest Monsoon was also enhanced by TC Maring. On 12 October 2021, the enhanced SWM brought moderate to heavy rains over areas in MIMAROPA.

The country is now experiencing the transition of the seasons albeit gradually. The weakening of the SWM, the strengthening of the high-pressure area over mainland Asia, and the expected northeasterly surge over Northern Luzon within the next five days, is indicative of the transition and that the SWM season or “Habagat” is over. The transition will lead to the gradual onset and progression of the Northeast Monsoon.

Onset of La Niña5
In another press statement released by DOST-PAGASA, recent oceanic and atmospheric conditions indicate the onset of La Niña, that is likely to persist until the first quarter of 2022. The phenomenon is usually associated with above normal rainfall conditions across most areas of the country. Forecasts suggests that four to six tropical cyclones are expected to enter/develop in the Philippine Area of Responsibility, most of which are anticipated to make landfall. There is a possibility that these TCs will enhance the Northeast Monsoon. 

LOCAL SITUATION:
-La Union:  Brgy. Rimos 3, 4 and 5 (knee to waist-level flood has subsided)

-Baguio City
Landslide at Dominican Mirador (Oct. 12); 1 house involved

results.name: GDACS Orange: Philippines VO
results.summary: Volcano Taal is emitting ash clouds according to the regional VAAC. The aviation alert level is Orange.

field_reports.description:
On July 1, 2021 at 3:37 PM, the Taal Volcano Main Crater was resported to generate a short-lived dark phreatomagmatic plume 1 kilometer-high with no accompanying volcanic earthquake. DOST-PHIVOLCS is now raising the alert status of Taal from Alert Level 2 to Alert Level 3.  

This means that there is magmatic intrusion at the Main Crater that may further drive succeeding eruptions. PHIVOLCS strongly recommends Taal Volcano Island and high-risk barangays of Agoncillo and Laurel, Batangas be evacuated due to the possible hazards of pyroclastic density currents and volcanic tsunami. he public is reminded that the entire Volcano Island is a Permanent Danger Zone (PDZ), and entry into the island as well as high-risk barangays of Agoncillo and Laurel is prohibited. In addition, communities around the Taal Lake shore are advised to take precautionary measures and be vigilant of possible lakewater disturbances related to the ongoing unrest. 

The whole province of Batangas is on monitoring. Communities in all municipalities and cities are on standby for possible escalation of the situation, Batangas Province has a total population of 2,694,335.

As per NDRRMC, a total of 113 barangays with 4,496 families/15,892 individuals were affected and a total of 1,128 families/3,888 individuals are currently staying in 23 evacuation centers.

TROPICAL STORM "SIONY" SLIGHTLY INTENSIFIES AND IS NOW INSIDE THE PHIILIPPINE AREA OF RESPONSIBILITY (PAR).
"SIONY" entered the PAR at 8:00 AM today. It is forecast to move generally northwestward until Monday evening, then slowly west-southwestward by Tuesday. It remains less likely to affect any portion of the country over the next 2 to 3 days. At 10:00 AM today, the center of Tropical Storm "SIONY" was estimated based on all available data at 1,365 km East of Central Luzon (16.0 °N, 134.3 °E ) moving west northwestward at 30km/h with a maximum sustained winds of 75 km/h near the center and gistiness of up to 90 km/h

field_reports.description:
Possible Scenarios

The possible effect of Typhoon ``Rolly'' as it is now Category 2 moving towards the Philippines with high possibility of landfall over Central and Northern Luzon, Southern Luzon, and may affect the entire Luzon regions. The following possible scenarios are developed for pre-disaster planning and anticipation of disaster events over highly threaten areas in Central and Northern Luzon and/or Southern Luzon:

●	Flooding caused by spill-over of water from major river basin and dams located in Central and Northern Luzon;
●	Landslide areas over mountainous provinces such as Mt. Province, Benguet, Ifugao, Rizal, Aurora, Nueva Vizcaya, Ilocos Regions and Southern Luzon;
●	Part of Aurora province may be isolated due to landslides;
●	Metro Manila particularly Quezon City, Valenzuela City, Caloocan City, Malabon City, and Navotas City will also be affected by flooding if over-spilled of water Dam in Angat and/or flood water coming from Bulacan;
●	High numbers of shelter be destroyed particularly in Eastern part of Luzon where mostly are made of light materials; 
●	High numbers of evacuees are expected due to pre-emptive evacuation before Typhoon will make landfall;
●	High damage or destruction on property and livelihood are expected along coastal areas due to strong storm surges particularly Aurora, Isabela, Cagayan, Apari, and part of Quezon provinces;
●	Basic lifelines particularly power, water, communication, transportation, fuel, and markets will be closed or will not functional during the onset of the disaster;
●	Access particularly those areas affected by landslides will be difficult; and
●	PRC Chapter with less DM capacity will be overwhelmed by the possible disaster operation scenarios. 

At 05:30 PM of Ocotber 30, 2020, the Tropical Cyclone East of the Philippines, with an international name GONI, entered PAR and named of TC “ROLLY” with a Severe Topical Storm category, and on 8:00 PM intensifies in a Typhoon.

And as of 03:00 AM today, the center of Typhoon "ROLLY" was located based on all available data at 1,185 km East of Central Luzon (16.4 °N, 133.2 °E ), with maximum sustained winds of 140 km/h near the center and gustiness of up to 170 km/h and is moving Westward at 20 km/h.

Track and intensity outlook:

Track: "ROLLY" is forecast to move west-southwestward or southwestward today until Saturday evening. Afterwards, the typhoon will turn more west-northwestward as it moves over the sea off the coast of Bicol Region towards the eastern coast of Central Luzon-Quezon area. On the forecast track, the center of the eye of "ROLLY" is likely to make landfall over the Central Luzon-Quezon area on Sunday evening or Monday morning.
 
Intensity: The typhoon is forecast to continuously intensify over the Philippine Sea and is likely to make landfall at peak intensity of 165-185 km/h.

Hazards affecting land:

Rainfall:
-        The rain bands of the typhoon will likely bring rains over Bicol Region and the eastern section of Northern and Central Luzon beginning on Saturday or Sunday.

Winds:
·       No locality is currently under Tropical Cyclone Wind Signal (TCWS) #1. However, in anticipation of the arrival of strong breeze to near-gale conditions due to "ROLLY", TCWS #1 may be raised over several provinces in the Bicol Region as early this afternoon. Given that it is likely for this typhoon to continue intensifying prior to landfall, the highest possible TCWS that will be raised throughout the passage of this typhoon will be TCWS #3 or #4 (associated with destructive to very destructive typhoon-force winds).

Forecast Weather Condition:

Impacts

Visayas, Bicol Region, Northern Mindanao and Caraga with Cloudy skies with scattered rain showers and thunderstorms through of TY Rolly possible flash floods or landslides during moderate to heavy rains.

Batanes and Cagayan cloudy skies with scattered rains and isolated thunderstorms with Northeasterly Surface Windflow possible flash floods or landslides during severe thunderstorms.

Metro Manila and the rest of the country partly cloudy to cloudy skies with isolated rain showers 
 with ocalized thunderstorms,possible flash floods or landslides during severe thunderstorms.

results.name: Philippines - Typhoon GONI
results.summary:
The impact of Typhoon Goni in in the northern central Philippines has been substantial, with devastating impact in certain localities particularly Bicol Region V – Catanduanes and Albay particularly appear to be hard hit. On the evening of 27 October 2020, a tropical depression developed over the Western Pacific Ocean, Northwest of Guam. Once inside the Philippine Area of Responsibility (PAR) it has been given local name “Rolly” (Goni). As per the state-run Philippines Atmospheric Geophysical and Astronomical Services Administration (PAGASA), Typhoon Goni made its landfall in Bato, Catanduanes, at 04:50 am local time on 1 November 2020.

Typhoon Goni made landfall as a super typhoon with maximum sustained winds of 225 kilometers per hour and gustiness of up to 280 kilometers per hour and moved west southwest at 25 kilometers per hour, making the second landfall over Tiwi, Albay at 07:20 am and the third landfall over San Narciso, Quezon at 12:00 pm.

At the time of landfall, PAGASA raised Tropical Cyclone Wind Signals as per the Bulletin #13. For Signal 5, it can be expected that there will be widespread damage to high-risk structures. Very heavy damage to medium-risk structures. Almost total damage to structures of light materials, especially in highly exposed coastal areas. Complete roof failure on many residences and industrial buildings. Electrical power distribution and communication services severely disrupted. Total damage to banana plantation. Most tall trees are broken, uprooted or defoliated. Coconut trees are stooped, broken or uprooted. Few plants and trees survived.

field_reports.description:
Track and intensity outlook:
•	"QUINTA" is forecast to exit the Philippine Area of Responsibility this morning. The typhoon is expected to further intensify over the West Philippine Sea and reach its peak intensity within 24 hours.
Hazards affecting land areas: 
•	Rainfall: Today, "QUINTA" will bring moderate to heavy rains over Western Visayas, Occidental Mindoro, Palawan including Calamian, Cuyo, and Kalayaan Islands, Aurora, Isabela, Cagayan and light to moderate with at times heavy rains over Zamboanga Peninsula, Bangsamoro, Northern Mindanao, Caraga, and the rest of Luzon and Visayas. Flooding (including flash floods) and rain-induced landslides may occur during heavy or prolonged rainfall especially in areas that are highly or very highly susceptible to these hazards. PAGASA Regional Services Divisions may issue local thunderstorm/rainfall advisories and heavy rainfall warnings as appropriate.
•	Strong winds: Strong breeze to near gale conditions will be experienced in areas under Tropical Cyclone Wind Signal (TCWS) #1. Potential impacts of these wind conditions to structures and vegetation are detailed in the TCWS section of this bulletin. In other areas, strong breeze to gale conditions associated with the northeasterlies will prevail in Batanes, northern Cagayan including Babuyan Islands, Apayao, and Ilocos Norte, while occasional gusts associated with the outer circulation of "QUINTA" will still be experienced over MIMAROPA, Western Visayas, and the western section of Luzon.
•	Coastal surf: Swells of 2.0 to 3.0 m due to "QUINTA" can cause significant breaking waves that may bring potentially damaging surf conditions over the western coastal areas of Pangasinan, Central Luzon, Occidental Mindoro, and Palawan including Calamian Islands.
Hazards affecting coastal waters:
•	Rough to very rough seas (2.5 to 5.5 m) will be experienced over the northern and western seaboards of Luzon. Sea travel is risky over these waters especially for mariners of small seacrafts.
•	Moderate to rough seas (1.2 to 2.5 m) will be experienced over the eastern seaboards of Central Luzon, Southern Luzon, and Palawan including Cuyo Islands, the southern seaboards of Mindoro Provinces, and the western seaboards of Western Visayas. Mariners of small seacrafts are advised to take precautionary measures when venturing out to sea. Inexperienced mariners should avoid navigating in these conditions.
•	Other tropical systems being monitored:
•	At 4:00 AM today, the Low Pressure Area (LPA) outside the PAR was estimated based on all available data at 1,855 km East of Southern Luzon (14.5 °N, 141.4 °E). This weather disturbance is likely to enter the PAR on Wednesday or Thursday. It is likely to develop into a tropical depression in the next 48 hours.
Location of Eye/center
At 4:00 AM today, the eye of Typhoon "QUINTA" was located based on all available data at 605 km West of Calapan City, Oriental Mindoro or 305 km North Northeast of Pag-asa Island, Palawan (13.3 °N, 115.6 °E ).

Impact of the Wind	•	Twigs and branches of small trees may be broken.
•	Some banana plants may be tilted or downed.
